It took hysterical possession of the newspapers, and led to questions in the House as to the cost of the police operation

For years Christie carried the visible taint of the story â€“ indeed, she never quite recovered from her assault by the 1920s equivalent of a Twitter mob

In December 1926 she  disappeared  for 11 days, almost certainly in a misjudged strategy for reclaiming the husband who wanted to leave her. 

When she was found alive and well in a hotel, after a nationwide search, her private mental anguish became the most public of scandals

ğŸ—ï¸Agatha Christieâ€™s understanding of the press derived, in part, from her first-hand experience of its excesses. 

Here, perhaps, is the strongest connection of all. 

Almost a century ago, Christie was in the eye of a tabloid storm as fierce as the one that now bears her name

ğŸ“–Coleen Rooneyâ€™s scheme to identify, by a process of elimination, the author of the anonymous leaks is somewhat reminiscent of Christieâ€™s 1943 novel, The Moving Finger.

The novel centres upon similar attempts to trace the source of a series of scurrilous anonymous letters

ğŸ“šAs for the  plot  aspect of the Wagatha saga â€“ this, too, would surely have appealed. 

There is even a vital missing clue, the phone belonging to Rebekah Vardyâ€™s agent â€“ also in the frame as a source of newspaper stories â€“ which now lies somewhere in the North Sea

ğŸ’·Christie herself grew up with little money, her amiable gentlemanly father having squandered most of it. 

She understood, always, the urgent need to acquire security â€“ understood, too, that there are many ways of earning it

She would certainly have  got  Coleen Rooney, the bright daughter of a Liverpool bricklayer who now lives in a Â£4â€‰million mansion.

Her books feature feisty girls full of wit, such as the heroine of The Sittaford Mystery who stops at nothing to save her boyfriend from the gallows

ğŸ“±Of course Christie would have loathed the contemporary trappings of this case, especially the ugly idiocies of social media (she never even enjoyed television).

Yet she moved with the times far more than is generally realised

ğŸ” Christie was a student of human nature, of motivation, and in essence that is what the Rooney-Vardy showdown is all about.

Two women, watched with who knows what feelings by their husbands, locking balayaged ponytails and refusing to back down

ğŸ—¨ï¸ One of her last known remarks, before her death in January 1976, was:  I wonder what has happened to Lord Lucan?  

Like most of us, she was fascinated by these real-life stories â€“ not least because her job required her to be

â¡ï¸However, that pervasive view of Christie does not quite square with the reality. 

The real Agatha Christie â€“ although a product of the upper-middle class into which she was born in 1890 â€“ was, in truth, a supremely unshockable cosmopolitan

The ongoing trial represents, one would think, an improbable culture clash with the genteel figure of Agatha Christie, whose tea-at-the-vicarage social landscape is one in which chipolatas are merely party sausages, and leaks are found only in drains

Each brother described, in great detail, stories of sexual abuse from their own father

â“What is Brexits impact?
 
If the UK was still a member state of the European Union, EU rules would insist migrants be returned to the first safe country in the bloc they landed in.
 
The UK is no longer part of those rules, which makes it more difficult to return migrants

â“Is it a migrant crisis?
 
There are fewer asylum claims and sea crossing in the Channel than other parts of Europe. Asylum claims in the UK have remained stable.
 
More than 416,600 new asylum claims were lodged in European Union member states last year

â“What is the process?
 
Most boats leave the Northern coast of France. This is often the culmination of a long and dangerous journey in the hands of criminal people smugglers.
 
Once in the UK, 98 percent  of the migrants claim asylum, which is a legal right

â“What is France doing?
 
Britain has two recent deals, worth Â£28mn and Â£54m with France to pay for increased surveillance of the coast.
 
Since Novemberâ€™s Â£28m deal, the French have stopped more than 18,000 attempted crossings

ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§Those who do attempt the crossing are likely to speak English rather than French or have family members already in Britain.
 
Others may come from countries with historical ties to Britain or places where the military has been active, such as Afghanistan

â“Why donâ€™t they stay in France? 
 
Many do.
 
Less than 3 percent  of refugees in Europe come to the UK.
